_header: Abide good man and hold your peace / And hear what God Himselven says until
_description: Appeal of Christ to man, ‘O vos omnes qui transitis’, etc. — three 6-line stanzas

BodDonC13.First Lines:
Habide gode men and hald ȝou stilAnd here what god sais
                    ȝou vntil…
BodDonC13.Last Lines:
…& in my mercie haue affiaunce& þou sal haue
                    grace
BodDonC13.Note:
Heading naming speaker, ‘Ihesus’ (f. 165vb);
                    followed by five stanzas of 3387.

BodRawPoe175.First Lines:
Abyde gud men & hald yhour paysAnd here what god him seluen
                    says…
BodRawPoe175.Last Lines:
…And in my mercy haue affyanceAnd þou sall gett my
                    grace
BodRawPoe175.Note:
Accompanied by Latin, ‘O uos omnes qui
                    transitis…’, very faint.
BodRawPoe175.Editions:
Reed,  Ernest Bliss. 
             Christmas Carols Printed in the Sixteenth Century
Huntington Library Publications.
         Cambridge, MA: Harvard UP, 1932 [= Kele, ca. 1550]: 59-60.
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 362-3.
Luria,  Maxwell Sidney,  and  Richard L. Hoffman, eds.  
             Middle English Lyrics.
         New York: Norton, 1974: 215.

BlCottGalEIX.First Lines:
Bides a while and haldes ȝoure paisand heres what god him
                    seluen sais…
BlCottGalEIX.Last Lines:
…and in my mercy haue affianceand þou sall get my
                    grace
BlCottGalEIX.Note:
54 lines in 6-line stanzas, aabccb. Rubric Latin heading above first
                    line: ‘Vos qui transitis: si crimina flere nelitis / Per me transite:
                        quia sum ianua inte’.
BlCottGalEIX.Editions:
Hall,  Joseph. 
             “Short Pieces from MS Cotton Galba E.ix.” 
             Englische Studien
         21 (1895): 201-9: 207.
 Bad Key: Horstmann1895-6: 2.457.
Fröhlich,  Walter. 
             De Lamentacione Sancte Marie: Eine englische Dichtung des 14
                Jahrhunderts.
         Leipzig: Heinrich John, 1902: 94.
